name: platinum group metal mine operation, ore with high palladium content | copper, cathode | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/833/documentation

This dataset describes the joint production of 0.73 kg of palladium, 3200 kg of copper, 2310 kg of nickel, 99.5%, 0.25 kg of platinum, and 0.02 kg of rhodium, in the Russian Federation in 2002. Palladium is the reference product, and all the remaining are byproducts. The module is designed for the use of the metal in technical systems, where it plays a minor role like the use in manufacturing of electronic or technical chemistry using certain catalysts. It is not to be used if the impact of the PGM within the modelled process in scope is considered to be high. In such cases, a more detailed analysis depending on scope and allocation procedures has to be conducted. The data used is mainly based on a LCA study for autocatalysts in Germany.

Mining process starting from ores, in ground.

The activity ends with the refining of PGM containing dross, at an external refining facility.

The dataset includes the beneficiation of the ore, the metallurgy of the ore, the separation of non-ferrous metals, the production of most agents used in beneficiation and metallurgy, the production infastructure for mining and metallurgy, and the disposal of overburden, tailings and slags.

The dataset doesn't include the handling of acid rock drainage from overburden and sulfidic tailings, nor the non-production infrastructure (such as buildings), nor the transport of mined ore from mining to beneficiation sites.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Some agents used like lime or sodium cyanide originate from data sets valid for Switzerland or Europe. Processes like blasting and transport originate from data sets valid for Switzerland or Europe.

exchanges.description: Literature value.

exchanges.description:

Further references: Hilbrans H. and Hinrichs W. (1999) Stoffmengenflüsse und Energiebedarf bei der Gewinnung ausgewählter mineralischer Rohstoffe; Teilstudie Nickel. In: Geologisches Jahrbuch, Vol. Sonderhefte SH 7. Bundesanstalt für Geowissenschaften und Rohstoffe, Hannover. ISBN 3-510-95829-2.

exchanges.description:
Extrapolation: Demand for water was not available for the process in RUS, it was approximated with the value for RSA (of 0.21m3 / t mined ore). 

Estimation: Two third of the water resource use in mining is assumed to be ground water, the rest is surface water.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value: Total electricity consumption values result from the addition of the consumption values of the following steps: Mining, beneficiation, metallurgy, separation of non-ferrous metals and refining.

MINING: 7.48E03 KWh

Estimation: The supply mix of the mining operations are estimated to be similar to that of the aluminum industry.

BENEFICIATION: 1.18E03 KWh

Estimation: Electricity production mix for the UCTE is chosen.

METALLURGY: 1.16E04 KWh.

SEPARATION: 5.56E03 KWh.

REFINING: 4.59E02 KWh

Extrapolation: Value corresponds to medium voltage electricity consumption from dataset 'platinum group metal mine operation, ore with high rhodium content, ZA 2002'.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value: Total water consumption value results from the addition of water consumption of the following steps: Mining, beneficiation, metallurgy and separation.

MINING: 6.28 m3

Extrapolation: Demand for water was not available for the process in RUS, it was approximated with the value for RSA (of 0.21m3 / t mined ore). 

Estimation: Two third of the water resource use in mining is assumed to be ground water, the rest is surface water.

BENEFICIATION: 31.7 m3

Estimation: 0.35 m3/t ore mined.

METALLURGY: 71.4 m3

SEPARATION: 827 m3

exchanges.description: Estimation: Lime was added in beneficiation which releases now fossil carbon dioxide. Flux is assumed to consist of 50% lime, which also releases carbon dioxide. 0.75 t flux per t matte is reported for copper in Krauss et al. (1999). Burning of 1 t lime (CaCO3) yields 0.44 t CO2.
